title: Learn SQL with Step-by-Step Visual Execution
cardcontent: Ananya wants to display student names with their department head. The details of department heads are stored in another table. INNER JOIN helps her link both tables!
card2content: INNER JOIN combines rows from two or more tables only when there is a matching value in both tables, based on the specified ON condition.

table1.title: Students Table (Alias: s)
table1.word: The first table (left side) containing student records.

table2.title: Departments Table (Alias: d)
table2.word: The second table (right side) containing department head records.

table3.title: INNER JOIN Output
table3.word: The result includes only students whose `department` exactly matches a `department` in the `departments` table.
table3.code: SELECT s.name, d.head FROM students s INNER JOIN departments d ON s.department = d.department;

table4.title: SQL Join Visualization
table4.word: The most crucial step in any join is defining the correct common column for the ON clause. This ensures records are matched logically (e.g., student's department matches department's name).
table4.code:
SELECT s.name, s.department, d.head 
FROM students s 
INNER JOIN departments d 
ON s.department = d.department;

multicont.word1: Identify the common column between two tables.
multicont.word2: Use aliases (e.g., s and d) for table names to simplify the query.
multicont.word3: Determine which columns from both tables are needed in the final output.
multicont.word4: Understand that INNER JOIN automatically filters out unmatched rows.
